description: From Middle English moment, from Old French moment, from Latin mōmentum. Doublet of momentum and movement.

entries.meaning: A brief, unspecified amount of time.
examples: Wait a moment, while I lock the front door.

entries.meaning: The smallest portion of time; an instant.

examples: The document in question is of such immense importance that its publication might very easily – I might almost say probably – lead to European complications of the utmost moment.

entries.meaning: (physics, mechanics) Ellipsis of moment of force.
(historical, unit) A definite period of time, specifically one-tenth of a point, or one-fortieth or one-fiftieth of an hour.
(neurology, informal) A petit mal episode; such a spell.
(mathematics) An infinitesimal change in a varying quantity; an increment or decrement.
(mathematics) A quantitative measure of the shape of a set of points.
examples: If the points represent mass, then the zeroth moment is the total mass, the first moment divided by the total mass is the center of mass, and the second moment is the rotational inertia.

entries.meaning: (Internet slang, derogatory) (As in "X moment") An embarrassing event, supposed to be characteristic of some person, group, or situation.
